data.value: Find the global minimum of a function using Dual Annealing.
The objective function to be minimized. Must be in the form
, where
is the argument in the form of a 1-D array and

Bounds for variables.
pairs for each element in
, defining bounds for the objective function parameter.
Any additional fixed parameters needed to completely specify the objective function.
The maximum number of global search iterations. Default value is 1000.
Extra keyword arguments to be passed to the local minimizer (
). Some important options could be:
for the minimizer method to use and
for objective function additional arguments.

The initial temperature, use higher values to facilitates a wider search of the energy landscape, allowing dual_annealing to escape local minima that it is trapped in. Default value is 5230. Range is (0.01, 5.e4].
During the annealing process, temperature is decreasing, when it reaches
, the reannealing process is triggered. Default value of the ratio is 2e-5. Range is (0, 1).

Parameter for visiting distribution. Default value is 2.62. Higher values give the visiting distribution a heavier tail, this makes the algorithm jump to a more distant region. The value range is (0, 3].

Parameter for acceptance distribution. It is used to control the probability of acceptance. The lower the acceptance parameter, the smaller the probability of acceptance. Default value is -5.0 with a range (-1e4, -5].

Soft limit for the number of objective function calls. If the algorithm is in the middle of a local search, this number will be exceeded, the algorithm will stop just after the local search is done. Default value is 1e7.

If

A callback function with signature
, which will be called for all minima found.
and

- 0: minimum detected in the annealing process.     - 1: detection occurred in the local search process.     - 2: detection done in the dual annealing process.
If the callback implementation returns True, the algorithm will stop.
Coordinates of a single N-D starting point.

This function implements the Dual Annealing optimization. This stochastic approach derived from [3]_ combines the generalization of CSA (Classical Simulated Annealing) and FSA (Fast Simulated Annealing) [1]_ [2]_ coupled to a strategy for applying a local search on accepted locations [4]_. An alternative implementation of this same algorithm is described in [5]_ and benchmarks are presented in [6]_. This approach introduces an advanced method to refine the solution found by the generalized annealing process. This algorithm uses a distorted Cauchy-Lorentz visiting distribution, with its shape controlled by the parameter

g_{q_{v}}(\Delta x(t)) \propto \frac{ \ \left[T_{q_{v}}(t) \right]^{-\frac{D}{3-q_{v}}}}{ \ \left[{1+(q_{v}-1)\frac{(\Delta x(t))^{2}} { \ \left[T_{q_{v}}(t)\right]^{\frac{2}{3-q_{v}}}}}\right]^{ \ \frac{1}{q_{v}-1}+\frac{D-1}{2}}}
Where
is the artificial time. This visiting distribution is used to generate a trial jump distance
of variable
under artificial temperature
From the starting point, after calling the visiting distribution function, the acceptance probability is computed as follows:
p_{q_{a}} = \min{\{1,\left[1-(1-q_{a}) \beta \Delta E \right]^{ \ \frac{1}{1-q_{a}}}\}}
Where
is a acceptance parameter. For
, zero acceptance probability is assigned to the cases where
[1-(1-q_{a}) \beta \Delta E] < 0
The artificial temperature
is decreased according to
Where
is the visiting parameter.
The following example is a 10-D problem, with many local minima. The function involved is called Rastrigin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rastrigin_function)

signature: dual_annealing(func, bounds, args=(), maxiter=1000, local_search_options={}, initial_temp=5230.0, restart_temp_ratio=2e-05, visit=2.62, accept=-5.0, maxfun=10000000.0, seed=None, no_local_search=False, callback=None, x0=None)
references: .. [1] Tsallis C. Possible generalization of Boltzmann-Gibbs
.. [2] Tsallis C, Stariolo DA. Generalized Simulated Annealing.
.. [3] Xiang Y, Sun DY, Fan W, Gong XG. Generalized Simulated
Annealing Algorithm and Its Application to the Thomson Model.
.. [4] Xiang Y, Gong XG. Efficiency of Generalized Simulated
.. [5] Xiang Y, Gubian S, Suomela B, Hoeng J. Generalized

Package for R. The R Journal, Volume 5/1 (2013).
